awd_titl_txt: Hidden in plain sight: Uncovering low-surface-brightness galaxies and their host dark matter halos
awd_abstract_narration:
Johnny Greco is awarded an NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellowship to conduct a program of research and education at the Ohio State University.  Greco will perform a systematic search for faint, diffuse galaxies known as low-surface-brightness galaxies (LSBGs).  Using a software that he created and optimized for the detection of LSBGs, he will aim to increase the number of LSBGs in new and existing optical observational surveys.  Greco will produce a public catalog of many thousands of previously unknown LSBGs spanning a wide range in properties, and he will perform detailed observations of some of these LSBGs.  Results from this study will allow astronomers to understand how LSBGs form and how they fit within the cosmological context.  Alongside this research, Greco will create educational projects designed to encourage high school girls to pursue careers in science and computer programming.

By building an unbiased sample of LSBGs, the proposed research will elucidate formation mechanisms of giant LSBGs, which will provide important constraints on theories of galaxy formation and evolution.  Furthermore, as systems predominantly composed of dark matter, LSBGs provide the most stringent tests of our current cosmological model.  By combining rotation curves, globular cluster studies, and possibly a stacked weak-lensing analysis, the proposed research will constrain the dark matter distribution in these galaxies on both small and large scales.  Working with an outreach program at his host institution, Greco will use his expertise in astronomical image processing and coding to design software and student projects to stimulate the interest of high school girls in science, and he will serve as a mentor to high school students interested in astronomy research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
After many decades of surveying the night sky, we now have a reasonably complete census of the brightest galaxies in the universe. However, it has long been recognized that there is a vast population of hidden galaxies, whose surfaces are too faint to be detected by our telescopes. Our census of these so-called low surface brightness (LSB) galaxies is severely incomplete due to the technical challenges of detecting and studying such diffuse objects. To push the surface brightness frontier of galaxy research, my project focused on the systematic discovery and characterization of these elusive systems.   

I led and/or contributed to three wide-field surveys for new LSB galaxies. The first was a continuation of my thesis work in which I developed custom image processing and galaxy detection software and carried out a blind search over hundreds of square degrees of the sky. My new sample consists of tens of thousands of LSB objects (more than an order of magnitude larger than my thesis sample), which will be the subject of future work from our group at Princeton University. In the second survey, we used existing public data to search for LSB satellite galaxies around massive hosts in the very nearby universe. Our work produced state-of-the-art measurements of the physical properties of LSB dwarf galaxies, as well as a new calibration for a powerful method for measuring galaxy distances. For the third survey, I developed an automated software pipeline that takes nightly images from the Dragonfly Telephoto Array and produces science quality images that are optimized for searching for LSB galaxies. This dataset will ultimately cover the entire footprint of the famous Sloan Digital Sky Survey, which spans over a third of the sky. 

To complement the above surveys, I carried out a detailed study of a technique for measuring distances to the nearest discovered systems. Using thousands of realistic image simulations of low-mass galaxies, I demonstrated the feasibility of measuring the distances to similar systems in current and future wide-field imaging surveys. In addition, I published a new theoretical calibration for this method, which will be useful for constraining stellar population models and estimating distances to old galaxies.  

 Finally, by expanding upon and generalizing the software I used in my distance measurement work, I developed an open-source software package for generating realistic image simulations of stellar systems. The package is called ArtPop, and it is designed to be intuitive to use and includes a set of pedagogical tutorials. My hope is that ArtPop will be useful for the astronomy community both for research and in the classroom, giving students a simple interface for performing advanced stellar population calculations and generating image simulations. The attached image shows a schematic diagram of how ArtPop generates an image simulation of a dense cluster of stars.

In addition to the science, a major focus of this program was broader impacts. To encourage high school students to become curious about science and coding, I developed an open-source software package that allows them to carry out complicated image processing tasks on galaxy images from the Hyper Suprime-Cam Survey -- the highest resolution ground-based survey in existence. Included with the software is a set of interactive notebooks, which guide students through a tour of coding, image processing, and stellar evolution. The software was a major component of Ohio State's ASPIRE summer program. Between this program and the pedagogical nature of ArtPop, a significant outcome of this project is a publicly available code base for students who are interesting in coding, image processing, and stellar populations and their images.
